abstract.text: A query interface that runs anchored object queries using Swift concurrency.

inlineContent.text: Use
to read any changes to the HealthKit store that occurred after the provided anchor. When creating a new query descriptor, if you pass
as the
parameter, the query reads all matching data from the store.
There are two common use cases for anchored object queries:
Batch-read all the matching data from the HealthKit store using a series of
instances.
Monitor the HealthKit store for any changes to the matching data using a long-running
instance.

Users may have large quantities of data saved to the HealthKit store; therefore, reading all data for a given data type might become very expensive, both in terms of memory usage and processing time. To avoid performance issues, you can use
queries to read the data in batches.
Start with a

-valued anchor, and create a one-shot query descriptor that reads a batch of data. After you process the results from one query, start a new one-shot query for the next batch. Continue reading batches until there’s no new data.

code: // Start by reading all matching data.
// Create a query descriptor that reads a batch
// Process the batch of results here.

inlineContent.text: Because
instances adopt the
protocol, you can save the most recent anchor and use it the next time your app launches.
To monitor the HealthKit store for changes, start by creating an
instance that matches the data you want to monitor. Pass in the anchor from the last time you read data from the HealthKit store.
Next, call the query descriptor’s
method to start your long-running query. This method returns an
instance which HealthKit uses to return
instances. The first result represents any changes currently in the HealthKit store, and additional results represent changes as they occur.

code: for try await update in updateQueue {

abstract.text: A type that provides asynchronous, sequential, iterated access to its elements.
A protocol that enables encoding and decoding in a manner that is robust against object substitution attacks.
Access and share health and fitness data while maintaining the user’s privacy and control.
A query for reading activity summary objects from the HealthKit store.
A query interface that reads activity summaries using Swift concurrency.
A query that returns changes to the HealthKit store, including a snapshot of new changes and continuous monitoring as a long-running query.
A query interface that runs anchored object queries using Swift concurrency.
A set of results from an anchored object query.
An asynchronous sequence that emits updates from an anchored object query.
An anchor that a previous anchored object query returned.
Creates an anchored object query descriptor.
The maximum number of samples that the query returns.
A predicate that limits the results that the query returns.
Runs a one-shot query and asynchronously returns a snapshot of the current matching results.
Initiates a long-running query that returns its results using an asynchronous sequence.
A protocol that defines an asynchronous method for running queries.
A protocol that defines a method for running queries that returns results using an asynchronous sequence.
A long-running query that monitors the HealthKit store and updates your app when the HealthKit store saves or deletes a matching sample.
An object used to identify all the samples previously returned by an anchored object query.
A HealthKit sample represents a piece of data associated with a start and end time.
Use queries to request sample data from HealthKit.
Use Swift concurrency to manage one-shot and long-running queries.
A type whose values can be implicitly or explicitly copied.
